title: Bob Kincaid Show - July 02, 2008 (24kbs Audio).mp3
description:
The Democratic National Committee released a video Wednesday documenting the numerous times presidential candidate Sen. John McCain (R-AZ) has admitted his ignorance on the economy.


Here&#039;s McCain, in his own words about himself:

On ABC News July 2, 2008:
Q: You have admitted that you&#039;re not exactly an expert when it comes to the economy and many have said -- MCCAIN: I have not. I have not. Actually, I have not.

McCain campaign town hall meeting in Concord, NH, Dec. 17, 2007:
MCCAIN: I am not an expert on Wall Street, I am not an expert on some of this stuff.

Before the Keene Sentinel editorial board, Dec. 4, 2007, regarding the housing crisis in New Hampshire:
MCCAIN: I can&#039;t come down now and give you a specific solution because I don&#039;t claim to be smart enough.

CNBC Republican Debate, Oct. 9, 2007:
Q: Has Ben Bernanke cut rates aggressively enough?
MCCAIN: I don&#039;t have that kind of expertise to know exactly whether he has cut interest rates sufficiently or not.

In an extended conversation with Tim Russert:
(In a debate)
RUSSERT: Senator McCain, you have said repeatedly, "I know a lot less about economics than I do about military and foreign policy issues. I still need to be educated." Is it a problem for your campaign that the economy is now the most important issue, one that by your own acknowledgement is something you&#039;re not well versed on?
MCCAIN: Actually, I don&#039;t know where you got that quote from. I&#039;m very well versed in economics.
(Later, on Meet The Press, Jan. 27, 2008)
MCCAIN: Now I know where you got that quote from. Now I know where you got that quote.
RUSSERT: I will show you where I got that quote from. I got it from John McCain, And here it is: "[McCain] is refreshingly blunt when he tell[s] me: &#039;I&#039;m going to be honest: I know a lot less about economics than I do about military and foreign policy issues. I still need to be educated." [quoted from The Wall Street Journal]

While it&#039;s widely accepted that the commander-in-chief can&#039;t directly control the economy, it&#039;d be good to elect someone who at least understands how it works. And with many polls showing the economy as voters&#039; number one issue, McCain would do well to hit the books.

Also try listening to Thom Hartmann,  Randi Rhodes,  Ed Schultz and Mike Malloy
